election_record.label: Pennsylvania 1812 Electoral College

overview.note: Election was held on Friday, October 30, 1812 for the Republican ticket of James Madison and Elbridge Gerry and the Federalist ticket of DeWitt Clinton and Jared Ingersoll.
David Meade was run on both the Madison and Clinton tickets.
DeWitt Clinton was supported by the Federalist Party and anti-war Republicans.
Joseph Hiester was withdrawn as a candidate and replaced by Nathan Palmer.
James Stephenson is also listed as James Stevenson and Abia Minor is also listed as Abiah and Abijah Minor.

Many newspapers report differing vote totals, at both the county and state levels. The listed returns for each county and the overall vote total are from the official returns. Within each county, individual township totals as reported by various newspapers have been included, some of which match the official county totals and others which differ for various reasons, such as returns which contain townships whose totals were officially rejected. Discrepancies have been noted where possible.
The vote totals listed include 298 Madison and 130 Clinton votes which were rejected from the counties of Armstrong, Dauphin, Fayette and Susquehanna.

There were 3,383 votes cast for Abijah Minor which have been included in the vote total of Abia Minor. There were also an undetermined number of votes cast for Joseph Sanson and Joseph Sampson in place of Joseph Sansom; for Joseph Martin and John Martin in place of James Martin; and for Jacob Heister in place of Joseph Hiester.

"The Election of twenty-five Electors, of President and Vice-President of the United States, will take place, under the direction of the same Judges, Inspectors and Clerks, who officiated at the late General Election, in several Election Districts, in this County, on Friday that 30th instant. The tickets prepared for the support of the Electors, are below, under their proper head--the Candidates for the Presidency, are both Democrats; the one (Clinton) is said to be a decided friend of a restoration of Commerce, and eminently qualified to prosecute a war with vigor, if rendered necessary; the other's qualifications are well known from experience; our readers, therefore, will take their choice of them." The Huntingdon Gazette (Huntingdon, PA). October 22, 1812.

"When we mentioned that some person or persons unknown had somewhere formed and published what they called a Clintonian Electoral Ticket we stated that there were some names upon it of men of principle and character who never had been consulted, and we were sure never would consent to be the candidates of the turbulent, the discontented and office-seeking among the republicans combined with "the British Party." That we were not mistaken has been already proved, and as further evidence we offer the following letter of Mr. Castor's of Philadelphia County. It does him credit and is but the forerunner of many similar publications. So hopeless, so forlorn and desperate are the hopes of Faction and Federalism in Pennsylvania that it will not at all surprise us if between this and the day of the Presidential Election, near as it is, one half of the whole Clintonian electoral ticket should declare off; nor in truth would it excite our wonder if the candidates themselves should fly the course and refuse to run a race in which they must be so utterly distanced as for ever after to be lost sight of. 'To the Publisher of the The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA). Sir- Having sufficient evidence to satisfy my conscience and judgment, that the democratic party throughout the Union consider James Madison as their candidate for the President and Elbridge Gerry, as their candidate for their Vice President, and that those gentlemen will receive the support of the great body of that party, I cannot consent to become an instrument for exciting any division or discontent. I am unwilling at such a crisis, to support any person in opposition to those gentlemen, the more especially as opposition is advocated by the Federal party. Those therefore who thought fit to place my name on the list of Electors of President and Vice President of the United States are hereby notified, that I will not support De Witt Clinton or Jared Ingersol, and that it is my earnest desire, that the republican party of Pennsylvania may give an entire and unanimous support to the Ticket, published in the Aurora and The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA). Samuel Castor. October 17, 1812.'" The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA). October 19, 1812.

"One election district in Fayette and one in Dauphin did not forward their return until after the proper return day~as there were no other irregularity, it is but fair to include them in the average majority." The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA). November 20, 1812. Country Edition.

"The Pennsylvania Republican (Harrisburg, PA) says: 'The average majority for Madison is 20,133. To which add 215 votes, given in one district in each of the counties of Dauphin and Fayette (not included in the general return) and the real majority is 20,348.'" The Intelligencer, and Weekly Advertiser (Lancaster, PA). November 21, 1812.

"Charles Thompson, Adamson Tannehill, Arthur Moore, and Charles Shoemaker, Electors of President and Vice President, had not arrived at the seat government. The Electors were, by law, to meet next day, when, if the above named gentlemen did not attend, the Assembly would choose four other persons to supply their places." The Freeman's Journal and Philadelphia Mercantile Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA). December 5, 1812.

"Extract of a letter from a member of the Pennsylvania legislature, dated Harrisburg, December 2, 1812. "The governor communicated to both houses, this day, that four of the electors of president and vice president were absent. A convention convened and elected to supply the place of Charles Thompson, with Walter Franklin; Charles Shoemaker, with Charles Shoemaker, Jr.; Arthur Moore, with Alexander Dysart; and Adamson Tannehill, with Joseph Reed. The votes given were 110, of which Walter Franklin, etc. had 89. John Glonginger, Alex. Graydon, James Hopkins and Thomas Elder had each 21!~So that the choice of Pennsylvania is fully secured for Madison and Gerry.'" The Reporter (Washington, PA). December 14, 1812.

"On Wednesday morning last the Legislature of Pennsylvania, by joint vote, proceeded to elect four Electors of President and Vice President of the United States. The Democratic candidates were Walter Franklin, President of the Court of Common Pleas for the 2nd district, Alexander Dysart and Joseph Reed, members of the House of Representatives, and Charles Shoemaker, Jr. of the Senate. The Federal candidates were John Gloniger, James Hopkins, Thomas Elder, and Alexander Graydon. The Democratic candidates had each 88 votes, and the Federal candidates 21 votes." The True American and Commercial Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA). December 7, 1812.

"Gen. Tannehill, it is probable, will not attend if elected, yet it behooves every republican to vote for him notwithstanding; otherwise, from the want of time to agree throughout the state on a new candidate, a federal-Clintonian elector might happen to be chosen in his place. By the above law all vacancies are readily supplied. Republican editors in the state would serve the cause of republicanism in noticing the above." Pennsylvania Republican (Harrisburg, PA). October 20, 1812.

sub_unit.name: Adams
sub_unit.note: In Adams County, 418 votes were cast for George Lemmel, Jr., which are presumed to have been cast for George Kemmel, Jr., and are therefore included in George Kemmel, Jr.'s vote total.

sub_unit.name: Versailles
sub_unit.note: Versailles township is also referred to as McKeesport.

sub_unit.name: Armstrong
sub_unit.note: "One of the judges of Sugar Creek township, Armstrong County, refused to sign the return, because David Meade was run on both tickets!~This gentleman was a true member of the opposition!" The Mercury (Pittsburgh, PA). November 5, 1812.

sub_unit.name: Beaver
sub_unit.note: Except for David Meade and James Boyd, for whom returns have been identified, all electors in Beaver County are credited with their ticket's vote total since individual elector totals have not been found.

sub_unit.name: Berks
sub_unit.note: Der Readinger Adler (Reading, PA) from November 3, 1812 provides vote totals for the districts of Berks County, however the totals add up to 3026 votes for the Madison ticket and 690 votes for the Clinton ticket.

sub_unit.name: Bucks
sub_unit.note: The Pennsylvania Correspondent, and Farmers' Advertiser (Doylestown, PA) from November 9, 1812 provides vote totals for the townships of Bucks County, but only for the overall Madison and Clinton tickets.

sub_unit.name: Butler
sub_unit.note: "In Butler County, the Madison ticket ran nearly unanimously. In Butler town and township, the Clinton ticket had 7 votes; in Centre, 4; in Clearfield, none; in Donnegal, 3; in Connequenessing, 3; and in Muddy Creek, 9. The other districts of this county have not been heard from, but will produce similar results." The Mercury (Pittsburgh, PA). Novembr 5, 1812.

sub_unit.name: Cambria
sub_unit.note: The official returns list 87 votes for the Madison electors and 48 votes for the Clinton electors. However, in the History of Cambria County, by Henry Wilson Storey, Vol. I. pg. 104, a source which includes township totals, the Madison ticket is listed with 89 votes and the Clinton ticket with 50. The county totals listed here reflect the official returns, but the township totals are also included. The reason for the difference in these two sources is not clear. Additionally, individual returns have been found for David Meade, David Mitchell, and James Boyd.

sub_unit.name: Haines
sub_unit.note: "Two fine, thriving fertile valleys [referring to Haines and Miles townships], settled cheifly with industrious, independent Germans, who never fail to turn out in a solid column when any great political question is at issue as the above statement shows. Captain Klekner's company of volunteers, now at Buffalo, supporting their country's rights, and protecting it from the British and their Savage allies, are from Hain's township--Between 40 and 50 votes were thereby lost, every one of which would have been for the Whig electors." The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA). November 11, 1812

sub_unit.name: Half Moon and Patton
sub_unit.note: The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from November 11 refers to this district as "the quaker district."

sub_unit.name: Clearfield
sub_unit.note: Clearfield County was attached to Centre County.

sub_unit.name: McKean
sub_unit.note: McKean County was attached to Centre County.

sub_unit.name: Dauphin
sub_unit.note: "The return [from Snyder's] had not come in at the time the general return for the County of Dauphin was made out and therefore not in the general return." Several sources published soon after the election report a lower vote total that the actual total. The totals listed here include the missing return.

sub_unit.name: Palmyra
sub_unit.note: Die Harrisburger Morgenrothe (Harrisburg, PA) refers to this township as Palmstown.

sub_unit.name: Snyder's
sub_unit.note: The return from Snyder's was not listed in the sources which published the electoral vote by townshiThe total for each ticket, however, has been inferred after comparing the early returns and the corrected returns which were later published.

sub_unit.name: Upper Paxton
sub_unit.note: Die Harrisburger Morgenrothe (Harrisburg, PA) refers to this township as Red's.

sub_unit.name: Fayette
sub_unit.note: Individual township returns from Fayette County were published in The Genius of Liberty, and Fayette Advertiser (Uniontown, PA) from November 5, 1812, however, the returns are incomplete. The newspaper explains, "No returns being made from Connellsville and Wharton districts, we are unable to give the amount of votes. We learn that the Madison ticket had a majority of 123 votes in Connellsville district." The Genius of Liberty, and Fayette Advertiser (Uniontown, PA). November 5, 1812. Furthermore, returns for James Boyd are no reported in The Genius of Liberty. Complete returns have been found for David Meade, David Mitchell, and James Boyd, but the totals listed here for all other electors are missing the totals from Connellsville and Wharton districts.

sub_unit.name: Connellsville
sub_unit.note: "We learn that the Madison ticket had a majority of 123 votes in Connellsville district." The Genius of Liberty, and Fayette Advertiser (Uniontown, PA). November 5, 1812.

sub_unit.name: Franklin
sub_unit.note: Except for David Meade, David Mitchell, and James Boyd, for whom returns have been identified, all electors in Franklin County are assumed to have their ticket's vote total since individual elector totals have not been found.

sub_unit.name: Jefferson
sub_unit.note: Votes from Indiana County include votes from Jefferson County.

sub_unit.name: Lehigh
sub_unit.note: The Gleaner (Wilkes-Barre, PA) from November 20, 1812 lists the Clinton ticket with 420 votes in Lehigh County.

sub_unit.name: Saeger's
sub_unit.note: Results from Allentown and Saeger's are published in The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) from November 3 as an "Extract of a letter to the editor, dated Allentown, Lehigh County. Nov. 1, 1812."

sub_unit.name: Luzerne
sub_unit.note: While official returns report 713 votes for the Madison ticket and 1245 votes for the Clinton ticket in Luzerne County, the totals published in The Gleaner (Wilkes-Barre, PA) from November 13, 1812 report 704 votes for the Madison ticket and 1248 votes for the Clinton ticket. Official returns from the county are listed here as are the township returns from The Gleaner, as no alternate returns listed by township have been found. The discrepancy should be noted between the two sources. Totals listed in The Gleaner contain votes from parts of both Bradford and Susquehanna Counties which appear to have voted with Luzerne County and may explain the differences in reported vote totals.

sub_unit.name: Bradford
sub_unit.note: Bradford County was created in 1810 from Luzerne and Lycoming Counties but some parts of Bradford continued to vote with Luzerne in this election.

sub_unit.name: Susquehanna
sub_unit.note: Susquehanna County was formed in October 1812 from Luzerne County but some parts of Susquehanna continued to vote with Luzerne in this election.

sub_unit.name: Willingboro
sub_unit.note: In 1813, Willingboro township was renamed Great Bend township.

sub_unit.name: Lycoming
sub_unit.note: The return from Lycoming County includes votes from townships in parts of Bradford and Tioga Counties.

The Lycoming Gazette from November 11, 1812 lists Abia Miner with 254 votes and Abijah Miner with 679 votes. It is presumed that these two candidates are, in fact, the same person, which gives Abijah Miner a total of 933 votes in the county.

The Lycoming Gazette from November 11, 1812 lists Joseph Hiester with 131 votes and Jacob Heister with 8 votes. It is presumed that these two candidates are, in fact, the same person, which gives Joseph Hiester a total of 139 votes in the county.

The Lycoming Gazette from November 11, 1812 lists Joseph Sansom with 254 votes, Joseph Sanson with 22 votes, and Joseph Sampson with 14 votes. It is presumed that these three candidates are, in fact, the same person, which gives Joseph Sansom a total of 290 votes in the county.

sub_unit.name: Big Island
sub_unit.note: According to a History of Lycoming County, there were several islands in the Susquehanna River which runs through the county. Over time, many of these islands just washed away. The biggest of these islands was called Bailey's Island, but the term Big Island is used in early election returns as a voting district.

sub_unit.name: Bradford
sub_unit.note: From 1812 to 1814, Bradford County was split into two voting districts. In this election, three townships voted with Lycoming and Tioga Counties, while the remaining districts of Bradford County voted with Luzerne County.

sub_unit.name: Potter
sub_unit.note: Potter County was attached to Lycoming County, but no distinct votes have been discovered.

sub_unit.name: Tioga
sub_unit.note: Tioga County voted with Luzerne County.

sub_unit.name: Mercer
sub_unit.note: In Mercer County, three votes were cast for John Ewig and have been included here in the vote total for John Emig. One misnamed vote each was cast in Mahoning, Sandy Lake, and Slippery Rock townships.

sub_unit.name: Montgomery
sub_unit.note: "Extract of a letter to the editor, dated Norristown, November 2d, 1812. 'I am extremely happy to have it in my power to inform you of the complete triumph of democracy in Montgomery county. Notwithstanding the exertions and the deceptive means used by the British faction, the Madisonian Electoral Ticket has successed by a majority of eight hundred and ten votes. Many individuals who have heretofore uniformly supported the federal ticket declared themselves openly and by their votes lent their interest in favor of the present measures of the administration on the election ground.'" The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA). November 3, 1812.

sub_unit.name: Northampton
sub_unit.note: Vote totals for the districts of Northampton County are published in the Northumberl. Republicaner (Sunbury, PA) from November 6, 1812. The totals add up to 1871 votes for the Madison ticket and 366 votes for the Clinton ticket. The individual totals have been included here, but it is unclear where the vote totals were altered in making out the official return.

sub_unit.name: Easton
sub_unit.note: "The Northampton Farmer states the number of votes for the Electors on Friday last in the Easton District, to be for Madison 411, and for Clinton 123." The Courier (Washington, DC). November 7, 1812.

sub_unit.name: Northumberland
sub_unit.note: Official returns list the Madison ticket with 3415 total votes in Northumberland County. The Northumberl. Republicaner (Sunbury, PA) from November 7, 1812 provides township totals for the county, but the individual totals reported add up to 3417 total votes.
In Northumberland County 252 votes were cast for Joseph Hiester and 22 votes were cast for Jacob Hiester. These votes have been combined to give Joseph Hiester a total of 274 votes in the county.

sub_unit.name: Deerstown
sub_unit.note: Deerstown is currently known as Lewisburg.

sub_unit.name: Swinefordstown
sub_unit.note: Swinefordstown is the local name for Middleburg township laid out on the land of John Swineford.

sub_unit.name: Youngmanstown
sub_unit.note: This township was later called Mifflinburg in honor of Thomas Mifflin, the first Governor of Pennsylvania after the 1790 Constitution, but originally was named for Elias Youngman and his family, the founders of the town.

sub_unit.name: Philadelphia City and County
sub_unit.note: The only sources which provide information for individual electors report a combined vote total from both Philadelphia City and County for each elector. For the candidates who received only one vote in the reported combined total, it has been attributed to Philadelphia County, though this is an assumption simply because it appears that the Philadelphia City return was more consistent and is less likely to have had additional votes. Returns within Philadelphia City and County were reported by overall election ticket.

sub_unit.name: Philadelphia
sub_unit.note: Official returns for Philadelphia City report 2937 votes for the Madison ticket and 2658 for the Clinton ticket. Early returns are reported in the Aurora. General Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA) from November 2 and list one less vote for each ticket. The individual totals are listed here, but are missing the one additional vote.

sub_unit.name: Philadelphia
sub_unit.note: Early returns vary slightly by source.

sub_unit.name: Byberry, Lower Dublin, and Moreland
sub_unit.note: This district is also referred to as Bustleton.

sub_unit.name: Orwigsburg
sub_unit.note: The Northumberl. Republicaner (Sunbury, PA) from November 7 states that in the Orwigsburg District "the Madison ticket had 358 and the Clinton 58 votes."

sub_unit.name: Warren
sub_unit.note: The returns for Venango County include the returns for Warren County.

sub_unit.name: York
sub_unit.note: Early sources report the Madison ticket with 2080 votes and the Clinton ticket with 1397 votes in York County. These are the only sources which report returns from individual townships, and so the totals have been included here to give an idea of the township votes, but are missing 10 votes for each ticket.
